stage.name: SCALING
stage.title: Business Model / Market Fit
stage.goal: Build systems and team to grow beyond founder-dependency
stage.subtitle: What got you here won't get you there. Time to build a real company.

lines: But here's the hard truth: YOU are now the bottleneck.
To scale, you need to build systems that work without you.
And you need to hire people who are better than you at their jobs.
This is where founders either level up or burn out.

stageEndCheck.convergenceLogic: AI ensures C11 and C12 fully assessed before stage completion

questions.questionText: MONTH 7: You have {{customers}} customers generating ${{revenue}}/month. Problem: You're working 70+ hours/week, support requests are piling up, development is slow, and the same issues keep recurring. What's your FIRST move?
questions.narrativeIntro: You've hit the founder capacity wall. Everyone does. How you respond defines your next phase.

scenario.context: Classic scaling pain. You're drowning in tasks that don't require your unique skills.
scenario.stakes: Your choice here determines whether you build a company or just a stressful job for yourself.

options.text: Hire customer support to handle the tickets
options.insight: Good first hire - frees you for higher-value work

followUp.questionText: What type of support person do you hire?

options.text: Full-time employee ($4K/mo)
Part-time contractor ($2K/mo)
Virtual assistant from overseas ($500/mo)
Build systems and automation to reduce manual work
options.insight: BEST: Systems scale infinitely, people don't

options.text: Pause new customer acquisition to catch up
Power through - hustle harder
options.warning: CRITICAL: This path leads to burnout

questions.questionText: MONTH 8: You notice the same customer questions coming in 10+ times per week. You're answering the same things repeatedly. What do you do?
questions.narrativeIntro: Repetition is the enemy of scale. Every repeated task is a system waiting to be built.

scenario.context: Support volume is growing with customers. You can't keep answering manually.
scenario.stakes: This is a test of whether you think in systems or just tasks.

options.text: Create an FAQ and knowledge base
Hire someone to answer them
Keep answering manually - it's personal service
Create video tutorials + automated onboarding emails
options.insight: BEST: Proactive education beats reactive support

questions.questionText: MONTH 9: Revenue is ${{revenue}}/mo. You need to scale product development. What's your approach?
questions.narrativeIntro: Product development is often the first thing that breaks at scale. How do you fix it?

options.text: Hire a senior developer ($8K/month)

followUp.questionText: Two weeks in, your new senior dev is moving slower than expected. Investigation reveals: your code has no documentation, no onboarding process, and unclear priorities. What do you do?

options.text: Let them go - they're not performing
options.warning: MISTAKE: The problem is YOUR systems, not them

options.text: Stop and build proper documentation and onboarding
Micromanage them through every task
Have an honest conversation and improve together
options.insight: EXCELLENT: Builds trust and solves root cause

options.text: Hire 2 junior developers ($6K total)
Stay solo and use freelancers for specific tasks
Bring on a technical co-founder

questions.questionText: MONTH 10: Your support team member comes to you: "The same issues keep recurring. Customers are frustrated. We're treating symptoms, not causes. Can we please fix the root problems instead of just responding to tickets?"
questions.narrativeIntro: Your team is giving you feedback. This is a test of whether you can receive it.

scenario.context: A team member is advocating for systematic improvement over firefighting.
scenario.stakes: How you respond determines your culture and their engagement.

options.text: Thank them and prioritize fixing root causes
Tell them to focus on their job - fixing root causes is your responsibility
Ask them to document the patterns and propose solutions
options.insight: BEST: Empowers team and gets valuable insights

options.text: Acknowledge but say you'll get to it eventually

questions.questionText: MONTH 10: A potential client offers you a $50,000 custom project. BUT: It requires 2 months of dedicated work, will derail your product roadmap, and the features won't benefit other customers. Do you take it?
questions.narrativeIntro: Custom work temptation. Every startup faces this. It's a trap that's hard to resist.

scenario.context: $50K is significant. But custom work rarely scales.
scenario.stakes: This decision reveals whether you're building a product company or a services company.

options.text: Yes - hard to turn down that cash
No - stay focused on the product for all customers
Negotiate: $75K with extended timeline to minimize disruption
options.insight: BEST: Gets value while protecting core business

options.text: Set up a separate services arm with dedicated team

questions.questionText: MONTH 11: Your first employee (6 months tenure) requests a 20% raise. They're good but not exceptional. Market rate for their role is +10% from what they're earning. You can afford it but it's tight. What do you do?
questions.narrativeIntro: People management moment. How you handle compensation reveals your leadership style.

scenario.context: They've been loyal. But 20% is above market, and you have limited resources.
scenario.stakes: This sets precedent for how you handle compensation across your company.

options.text: Give the full 20% - retain them at any cost
Offer market rate (10%) and explain the reasoning
10% now, another 10% at 1-year mark tied to performance
Decline - you can't afford any raise right now
Have a deeper conversation about their goals and explore non-cash options

questions.questionText: MONTH 11: A well-funded competitor launches a similar product with aggressive pricing. Three of your customers have already churned to them. What's your response?
questions.narrativeIntro: Competition has arrived in force. This is where leaders separate from followers.

scenario.context: Your market is being disrupted. You have less resources than the new competitor.
scenario.stakes: Your response here could determine whether you survive or thrive.

options.text: Match their pricing
options.warning: WARNING: Price war with a better-funded competitor is suicide

options.text: Double down on your value differentiation
options.insight: GOOD: Compete on value, not price

options.text: Accelerate your roadmap - build features they don't have
Talk to the churned customers - understand why they left
options.insight: BEST: Learn from loss, possibility of win-back

options.text: Panic - cut costs and team to survive

format.positiveSignals: List specific decisions that showed competency
format.negativeSignals: List specific decisions that showed weakness

stageTransition.narrativeIntro: You've built systems and a team. The business can run without you doing everything. Now comes the final test: can you lead through crisis and maintain your values under pressure?

timeAdvance.narrative: Month 12. The final stretch. You're close to your goal, but challenges remain.
